title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices to study laws and regulations affecting Federal campaigns, make recommendations for change, and consider various aspects such as campaign financing, candidate qualifications, trust in the political process, media access, and other relevant matters. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes a 9-member Commission from the private sector, with appointments made by various political leaders. The chairperson is selected by majority vote within 7 days, and if not done within 30 days, current members are discharged. The Commission shall meet at the call of the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. Each member is entitled to compensation for their duties. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A quorum consists of 6 members, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. SEC. 5. The chairperson can appoint staff without following standard procedures and may procure temporary services. SEC. 6. Recommendations and fast track procedures are implemented. SEC. 6. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing their study. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, which if agreed upon by 6 or more members, will be prepared as bills for expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act.
